The cell register establishes Mr Chairperson, that Victor Keswa was in prison at the relevant time.
What is the relevant time here?

Actually Chairperson, he was detained two times, first in March and thereafter released, but the most important one is May where he was detained in May and then released only on the 27th of June 1992.
When was he detained in May, on the 27th of May?
Okay, and then he remained according to the cell register, in custody until the 27th of June?
Okay, shall I record that fact.
One other aspect which may not be that important is that on the 18th of June, he was taken out of prison to court, and then returned on that very same day, on the 18th of June.

You see, I am just concerned that these loose documents may well get lost.  Perhaps they should constitute some kind of a bundle, which we can then give the next alphabet and then - so that if there is any reference to them, we can know what documents you are referring to.  Okay, but anyway, shall I record what you have just ...   The first document that you are handing in, is a cell register, relating to Vanderbijlpark Police station?
Pardon sir, sorry, I didn't get your words.
The first document you are handing in, is the cell register which relates to the Vanderbijlpark Police station?

Okay.  Should we give this a separate exhibit perhaps?   The last exhibit was V wasn't it?  The last alphabet is Z, isn't it, so after Z, there will be no more exhibits.  No more exhibits after that.  Okay, the cell register, will then be marked Exhibit W.   I am simply going to record that it shows that Victor Keswa was last detained as from what - is it the 5th?
From the 27th of May 1992 and remained in custody on 27th of June 1992.
On 18-6-1992 he appeared in court, he was taken to court, right?  What is your next document?
The next document is the occurrence book.
I am sorry Chairperson, just before Mr Mapoma puts in another exhibit, are you recording that what these cell registers establishes as a fact, that Victor ...
No, no, I am recording what appears on the face of the document, that is all that I am recording.
Because there seems, just by glancing through it, there seems to be problems with sequencing.
Sequencing for example.  If one has a look at the...
We do have the original Chairperson, I will make it available.
Okay, if there are certain problems that Mr Berger would like to highlight, have you had sight of the original?
Would it not be better that you make the original available to all the legal representatives and once you have done that, and let's see whether there is any agreement as to what appears on its face.

Okay, all right.  I will leave this as it stands for the moment, but it can always be expanded on or dealt with subject to what you are going to advise us after you had gone through the record, the original.
All right, so the next document would be the occurrence book, is it?

Okay, shall we mark that X, all right.  I am not going to record, is there any issue for this one?  You haven't seen the original either, okay fine.  Shall we - I wonder whether in view of the fact that they haven't seen the original so as to see whether there are any problems with this document, shouldn't we hold onto admitting these documents?  We can give them numbers.
Okay, very well.   So the next one is OC book, X, right, and then the third document?
It is a visitors' register, prison.
Sorry Mr Mapoma, it is not a register, it is an application to visit.
It is a permit.  It is not an application for a visit, it is a permit.
Yes.  This is the permit you fill in when you visit a prisoner, not the actual register you sign in the prison.
Yes Mr Chairman.  But the substance of it Chair, is to show that somebody did appear to visit a prisoner on that particular day.
Well, I will simply record this as being a permit for a legal visit to the prison.
That will be Exhibit Y, is it?
All right, would you therefore make available the original to these documents and then advise us Monday what the situation is.
Yes, very well, thank you.  Is that all?

(continued)  Mr Chairman, after dealing with the documents, I have also got a document and seeing that there is only one exhibit number, I want to grab at that opportunity to hand it in.  I've got the original with me as well, that is minutes of the Ulundi conference held on the 18th of July 1992 and the 19th of July 1992.
We have made copies, can I just ask to hand out the copies.  The original will be available for insight, I will keep it with me.
What is it that you are handing in?
The minutes of the National Conference of the Inkatha Freedom Party, held at Ulundi on the 18th and 19th of July 1992.
Have the other legal representatives seen that?
No.  We have made copies, I only received this document yesterday afternoon, so we made copies, it is available now.  Will it be convenient to distribute them now, Chairperson?
All right, yes, now these documents, these are the minutes of the Inkatha Freedom Party is it the 17th Annual General Conference, held between the 17th and the 19th of July 1992?
That is correct Chairperson, that is so, Chairperson.
Okay.  The second document, is this a continuation of ...
Chairperson, yes, that is also part of the minutes.  It starts on the 19-7-1992, but on page it looks like 6, there is an indicated that these minutes, it happened on the 18-7-1992.
Okay, we've got the 18th, all of them are recorded on the 18th, aren't they, and then the second part relates to the 19th?
The 19th, but there is also a portion that relates to the 18th, the second part of the second document.
What was the last Exhibit that you had submitted?
The last number that was given, was Y.
I mean that the applicant had handed in, can you still recall?  Was it U?

Okay, well, I suppose let's just give them, we will give the first one which has a heading of "The Conference", Z.  Shall we say Z1 and Z2?  How does one refer to the pages now of the conference?  Shouldn't we just number them from Z1 all the way through to the end?
I will accept that Mr Chairman.
Shall we just call them Z and then you can call it Z1 and all the way through?
Chairperson, could these documents be admitted as purported minutes and the reason that I say that is because you will see from Exhibit T ...
Yes, I am aware of Exhibit T, the response to the request for these things.

And the Inkatha Freedom Party said they have no minutes, so we don't accept these at all.  If I may just add, I have asked my learned friend if we could have sight of the originals of those documents.

Thank you Chair.  Mr Nosenga, I want to show you Exhibit M2, the aerial photograph of the Boipatong township and Slovo Park township.  Again just to put you in the picture, I want to point out certain points and then ask certain questions.  You indicated to me yesterday that the casspirs originally gathered in that open veld area across the factories, is that correct?
Yes, that is what I said.

And then you also indicated that, or you testified that the place where you entered the township, was approximately in the middle of the township, and I am going to indicate approximate middle of the township where the vehicles entered, is that correct?
Now today you gave evidence about five houses that you went into, would that be houses more or less in the area shortly after you have entered the middle of the township?
Yes, that is correct.  Even though I cannot see clearly, but that is how it is.

Yes, and then you said that you carried straight on with the road.  If I indicate a route, would you agree with that?  I am going to indicate in the middle of Boipatong township going down to the centre of the township, is that the route that was followed?
I do not see quite clearly here.  It is mixed up here, I cannot follow.  I said we went into the first house.
I don't want you to point out specific houses.  Let me point out Slovo Park to you, do you see the Slovo Park area which I am pointing out to you now?  Do you see that?
Yes, yes, I can see Slovo Park.
From the place where you entered Boipatong you said you went straight down and then made a turn and went further down to Slovo Park, is that correct?
Yes, yes, we took the main taxi route.
Yes.  If I point to you that the shops are in the vicinity, in the middle of the township there is some open space there, in that vicinity, would you agree with me the shops are somewhere there?
Yes, there is a shop there if not shops, near the ranks.
Yes.  And then you continued further down until you get a place close to Slovo Park where you also see trees, are those the trees you referred to?
Yes, those are the trees I was talking about.

Then you said that the casspirs came to a standstill.  I want you to indicate if it is possible for you, to indicate more or less where these casspirs came to a standstill, the four casspirs.  Was it close to the trees?
They came to a standstill on the street, they did not get into the shacks.  These are the shacks here.
Chairperson, just for record purposes, the witness  indicates a position just left of the trees as depicted on the photograph, the open space.
He has indicated on Exhibit M2 is it?
M2?  Right, would you show us?
Yes, can I mark it with a circle, the indicated position of the - is that right?
Yes, these are the shacks, these are the trees, the casspirs came to a standstill on the streets.
Show your other colleagues first, yes.
Mr Chairperson, is it possible that the Interpreters be furnished with the map, so that we can interpret correctly as it has been stated?
Do you have an extra map?
Unfortunately we do not have an extra map available.
I have given them a copy.

You also said something about a hostel, and that hostel is where you passed on your way back.  Now can you point out a hostel on this map or give an indication more or less where this hostel is?  To make it easier for you Mr Nosenga, is it close to Slovo Park or the middle of Boipatong, on the side of Boipatong, or can you give any indication where this hostel is?
I did indicate that we left the hostel behind in the township.   On your way actually to Sharpeville, you can actually see Slovo Park.  I cannot see quite clearly.
Let me ask you like this, you have indicated the route that was followed through the township, passed the shops, then directly down to Slovo Park.  Did you follow that same route going back?
We came back on the very same direction.
Then according to you Mr Nosenga, the hostel must be on that route again?

Yes, it is possible it is on the same route.  When we left Slovo Park, when we went to Boipatong there is a hostel after we have left Slovo Park, and there is a very big shop there and there is a taxi rank on the side, and we took the tar road, the main taxi route that is going up.
The hostel and the taxi ranks are not very much far apart.  The hostel can be perhaps at the distance as I have pointed out.
What is the distance, it is about four, five paces, metres?
As the Committee pleases.  Okay, is that the distance between the hostel and the taxi rank?

The taxi rank is not far from the hostel, it can be here, that is the place that I am pointing here.  You can actually see the hostel from the taxi rank.  There are shops and there is also this main taxi route that is going up.
The houses I mean in this hostel, are they the same as the houses in Boipatong, are they different?
Yes, that is correct.  There are houses there next to the hostel.
Yes, but what I want to find out is the houses in the hostel, do they look the same as the houses in the township?
The hostel is close to the houses.  I really don't know how to explain this,  I have just explained to you how far the hostel is in relation to the taxi rank.
The houses of the hostel, the houses that comprise the hostel, are they the same as the township houses?
No, I think they are not the same.
I think they are - I don't know how to explain this.  They have a somewhat fading white paint.
They are big, I am just not in a position to say.
Are they patterned along the same township houses?
No, they are not the same, the hostel houses are different.  You see in the township you have streets in between the houses, the hostel is somewhere in that place.  I don't know how to explain that.
This hostel you are referring to, is it a multi-storey building or just a single storey building?
You are mumbling something, we can't hear you.
I cannot say whether it is ...
The legal counsel is asking whether it is a facebrick building or not.
He is enquiring whether the hostel is a double storey or not?
In any event, after the shooting at the hostel, the four casspirs then left the group behind, is that right?
That is correct, the casspirs left.  The group was left behind.
Yes, now after the group was left behind, did you shoot, did you fire any further shots?   Sorry, yes after the casspirs left from the hostel, did you fire any shots in Boipatong or not?
No, I did not fire any shots.  I last fired my gun at Slovo Park.
Then did this group left the Boipatong township at the same place where you had originally entered the township?
You have indicated earlier in your evidence the place where you entered with the casspir, now all I want to know, did you exit the township also at that place?
Do you know which route did you follow to get to the tar road where you said you were walking when you went back to the hostel?

If I remember correctly, we took the main taxi route which joined the road to kwaMadala hostel and the factories nearby, we did not take the road to Vereeniging but opted for the one that move towards the hostel.

Yes, I accept that, well you said that you took the tar road in front of the factories, and I can point you to the road, is that the road?  There are the factories and that is the tar road, you walked on that road back to the hostel, is that correct?
The main road, the route that joins Boipatong and kwaMadala hostel.  It joins Iscor and Boipatong.
Yes, that is the - I think the name of the road is Noble Boulevard?

But my question in fact is, from the hostel to the tar road, did you follow a straight line, did you go in one street, directly to the tar road or did you move through the township, through many streets to get to the tar road or did you just take one road, straight to the tar road?
As I stated before, we did not change directions.  We just walked along that route in Boipatong and joined the street that leads you to Boipatong, to Madala hostel.  That is the route we took.
Mr Nosenga, you said that you took a TV, a video and money?  Did you take the video in Boipatong township?
That is correct, the TV, video and cash.
Did you take that in the houses you went into, one of the five houses you went into initially?
You also said and you must correct me if I am wrong, that the TV and the video was loaded into the casspir in Slovo Park, where it was parked, is that correct, to be transported back to the hostel?
This television set, can you describe the size, was it a big screen, a small screen or can you indicate the size?
It was a big screen TV.
What is the size, how big was it?
A big one?  What 51 cm?  Is it 67 or 51?
Yes, the indication is the big one.
About 66 cm's, that is the big size, the screen size I think.
I am, the screen is 51, the size of the TV is bigger, but I can't guarantee the make.
I know that is the medium size, but I will accept that for cross-examination purposes, 51 cm.   Now, you carried this television set and the video for some period, is that correct?
I loaded them onto the casspir.  The only thing that I held onto was the cash.
Yes, you said that the goods, the TV and the video, were loaded into the casspir at Slovo Park, so you must have carried it some distance?
No, I did not say so.  I did not say Slovo Park, I never mentioned Slovo Park.  I loaded them onto the casspir in the township.

Mr Nosenga, I asked you specifically where the loot was loaded into the casspirs and I mentioned the position where the casspirs came to a standstill in Slovo Park, in the road there where you indicated, and you said yes?
You only questioned me on the property just now.
Just a minute ago, Counsel asked you whether the TV and the video were loaded into the casspir as Slovo Park and your answer was yes.
No, I said at the township.

Yes, no, no, he is not saying that you took the items from Slovo Park, all that is being put to you at this stage is that you said the items that were stolen, were loaded into the casspirs at Slovo Park, which is where all the casspirs were.

No sir, the goods were loaded in the township.  I must have misunderstood that question.  As I said before, there are some questions that I do not understand.  I stole the goods from the houses in the township and that is where I loaded them onto the casspir.
No one is suggesting that you stole anything from Slovo Park, but what is being put to you is that it is at Slovo Park where all the stolen items were loaded into the casspirs.
No, I must have misunderstood.  He questioned me on how the casspirs proceeded to Slovo Park, but I did not say that the goods were loaded onto the casspirs at Slovo Park.
Are you saying that he only asked you about how the casspirs followed one another to Slovo Park, is that the question that you heard?
The question related to the goods, I just heard of it now.
Yes, okay.  Now from which house did you steal the TV, the video and the money, the first, the second, the third, the fourth or the fifth house?
I think it was the third house.
I think that is where I removed property from, yes, the third house.
All these three items, the money, the video and the TV?
Yes, I removed all of them from one house.
And you put them straight onto the casspir?
Yes, I loaded them onto the casspir as we walked along the street, then the Police were busy shooting at people in the street.
Who said you must load them onto the casspir?
Now apart from yourself, did the other people in your group also take things which they put into the casspir?
Yes, many people stole property.  I am not the only person who stole from Boipatong.
Was there any other people in your group that stole TV's?
Yes, some people did and they also stole items of clothing and food if I remember correctly, as well as cash.
And all of this was loaded into the casspir?
Sir, everything was loaded onto the casspir.  Some were, some property was loaded onto the other casspirs, but I only noticed the ones that were loaded onto my casspir.
How do you know stolen goods were also loaded into the other casspirs?

The people mentioned it.  I only concentrated on the casspir that I had been travelling in.  The items that were  burnt at the hostel, at Madala hostel, could not have been carried just in one casspir.  There were many items that were burnt at the hostel.
The question is, you didn't see other items being loaded into the other casspirs?
I just heard, I did not see them loading the goods into the casspir, but I was told that other items had been stolen from Boipatong.
When the casspirs left the group behind, they went onto the hostel, is that correct?
That is correct, they proceeded to kwaMadala hostel.
When you got back, were these casspirs still there at the hostel?
No, I did not see them again.
When the casspirs left you behind, I am talking now to the casspir you travelled in before, did the Policemen in that casspir, leave with that casspir?
Did the Policemen leave in that casspir?  Did they travel in that casspir from the hostel?
Yes, they left in the casspir.  It was only the hostel residents who followed on foot.
No, he rode in the casspir as an induna.

Gatchene was an induna, he rode with the Police and the casspir that had been escorting us in the township.  There were many items and Gatchene went on, rode on the casspir when they went to deliver the stuff at the hostel.
The other people walked on foot back to the hostel?
Do you know who off-loaded the items at the hostel?
No, I do not know who off-loaded the goods, I just saw them at the hostel.
Where did you see the goods again at the hostel?
They were inside the yard, the goods were inside the yard.  There was a main gate at the hostel and there is an open space near that gate and that is where I found that goods.
And the goods you found there, were those the goods not only from your casspir, but from all the casspirs?
That is so, there were many items that I saw.
How did you know which items are the items you stole in Boipatong?
I could recognise them because I had only stolen two items, the TV and the video and I took them.
As we understand from you, all the stolen items from the four casspirs were put together on the ground, inside the hostel?
Yes, we understood that, now what he wants to find out is how did you know that this is the television set that you stole and this is the video that you had stolen, how did you identify the goods?
I recognised them because the TV set that I had stolen, was big.
Did you identify them by the size?
You don't know what the make of that TV was?
I don't know, I am not educated.
What about the video, how did you manage to identify the video?
It was flat and that small.  I recognised that this was mine, and it was black in colour.
Was it the only video that was there?  There were no other video's there?
There were other TV's and some other items that I could not recognise.
So there was just one video and you knew that you had stolen the video, so this must be your video?
Sorry Mr Strydom, what time did you come back to the hostel, do you know?
Was it at night or was it ...
It was at night, I cannot remember the time.
Did you collect these goods at night?
Yes, there are lights inside the hostel.  We collected them after they had been delivered by the casspir inside the hostel.
On your way back to the hostel, did you see any vehicles travelling in the street you were walking in?
Yes, there were cars travelling along the main road.
Private vehicles or military vehicles or Police vehicles or what kind of vehicles did you see?
I just saw private vehicles, I did not see military vehicles.
Did you see anyone of the attackers in your group, firing shots at any vehicle?
No, I did not see anyone firing.
In the township, did you see any person breaking windows?
Yes, I did see people breaking windows, but I cannot identify them, because I went inside the houses.
So you can't identify any person that broke windows?
No, I cannot tell a lie.  I do not know who broke the windows.
Why did you state in your evidence in chief that you remember one of your fellow attackers breaking windows, and you gave the name of Stikenauw?
I do not remember that properly.  I said Stikenauw had told me that he had raped a woman.

I want to put to you and I've got the note here right in front of me, that you said that Stikenauw told you that he raped - you connected Stikenauw with something that was said about the rape, I agree with that, but before that you said I remember the fellow attackers breaking windows and you then, in that context also mentioned Stikenauw, so why are you changing your version?  Why can't you remember that?
No, I don't know about that.
Do you deny that you said that Stikenauw broke windows?
I don't know what you mean when you say "don't know."  Can you tell me, do you remember him breaking windows or didn't you see him breaking windows?
Sir, I said I did not see anyone.  They did break windows, but I went inside the houses.
I want to put to you that maybe hundreds of houses' windows were broken, you can't state that you saw any one of the people with you that broke a window?  Why not?
I did not see anybody breaking windows.
Am I correct when I say that many, many houses' windows were broken or is that a wrong statement?
I will not dispute that.  I will not dispute it.
Did you yourself break any windows?
No.  I did not break any window.
In one of those first five houses, did you see anybody breaking windows there?
No sir, I stated before that I did not see anyone breaking windows.  I went into the houses to deal with the business at hand.
I want to put to you that today you stated that in one of those houses, I think the third or fourth house, the group broke windows, some people of your group, broke windows.  Do you remember that?
This story that you state that Stikenauw said something about rape, what did you hear?
He told me that he had raped someone in Boipatong.
When did he tell you that?
On your way back to the kwaMadala hostel on the night of the attack or what, or when?
I just want to know you said he told you after the attack, now I want to know, was that on the way back when he told you that, back to the hostel?
He told me on the same day, after the attack.
Once again, you are mumbling something.  I want to hear your Zulu words, just speak up please.
I said he told me on the same night of the attack, after the attack.
Did you say the same night of the attack, after the attack, is that what you said?
It was after the attack on the 17th.
But just before that you said on the day after the attack?

I believe that maybe I misunderstood you, so maybe that is the problem, but I heard that.  In any event, you say that on the same night it was said?  Where was Stikenauw and yourself when this was said?
Do you know the room number?
No.  I only know my room number, room 3.
Why did you go to his room after the attack?
I went to his room and thereafter I went to my own room, that is after we had been to the stadium to drink ntelezi.
When you got to the stadium after the attack, who, which leader was there at the stadium?
Bekhi Chonco.  I do not remember the others.
Mr Nosenga, what was your answer to the question, why did you go to Stikenauw's room?
I said that at that time I had not gone to bed, so I went to his room, thereafter I went to my own room.  I said I went to Stikenauw's room ...
What he wanted to find out is why did you go there.
I had just gone there to visit.
So you say at the stadium was Gatchene and Darkie, Prince Vanana Zulu was not there?
I do not remember well.  According to - well, let me make a statement - was he the leader of the whole hostel, Vanana Zulu?
I knew Mtwana Zulu to be an induna at the hostel.
But you don't remember seeing him at the hostel after the attack, at the stadium after the attack?
Sir, I said I did not see him.
I said I did not see him at the stadium.
Tell me, the muti or ntelezi, did you get some of that after the attack?
Yes, it was given to us at the stadium.
It was just placed on the ground and every person was free to drink.  I drank it of my own free will.
But you don't know who put it there on the ground so that you can take it?
No.  We also returned the firearms to the stadium and Darkie Chonco removed them.
So you just drank some of that ntelezi?
Yes, I did drink it.  It was for cleansing.

I want to read your statement, page 22, paragraph 24, the middle of the paragraph
"... we then washed by a certain muti provided by Chief Mtwana Zulu."
	What do you say about that?
I do not know anything about that.  I did not see Prince Zulu there.

It goes further
"... we were all happy, chanting and singing."
	Did that happen?
That is so.  We did sing at the stadium and we were all excited.
"We were praised, especially by Mtwana and Gatchene and told that we did a great job"?
I do not know anything about that.  I did say that I did not see Mtwana.  What we did was to place our weapons on the ground, in a pile, the same weapons that we had used in the attack.
So this is again something that appears in this statement that was not coming from you?
I do not know the contents of that statement.
You say you put your firearms, the weapons on the ground of the hostel?
We returned them to the stadium, we put them on the ground and Darkie Chonco collected them.
So nobody praised you there at the stadium there after the attack, stating that a great job was done?
No, I don't know anything about that.  We did sing and we were happy, but I don't remember anybody congratulating us.
Do you know what Darkie Chonco did with the weapons?
They were stored in the ceiling once again.
He is the one who removed them from the ceiling in the first place.
Is the situation that Darkie Chonco removed the firearms from where they were hidden in the ceiling and put them in the stadium?
So after the attack, you put the weapons on the stadium?
Yes, from where he removed them.
And then Darkie Chonco removed them and hid them where he had removed them from?
You didn't assist him doing that?
No, I did not assist him.
If your statement reads "we hid the weapons in the ceiling of the hostel", that is again wrong?
I don't know about that, I did not hide any weapons.  I did not handle firearms, but I would be given one as an IFP member, but it was not my responsibility to look after them.
How do you know that the weapons were hidden in the ceiling on that night?
We were at the stadium and we placed our firearms there and Darkie Chonco was the person who removed them and Themba Khosa and I (indistinct) on the 18th, to collect them.
But you can't really say where Darkie Chonco put the firearms after the attack?
He did take them to the ceiling, that is where the firearms were always hid.  That is where we stored our weapons at the hostel.
That ceiling that you refer to, that ceiling is there at the showers, is that right, or not?
That is far from the stadium, is that correct?
So from the stadium, you can't see what is going on at the showers?
Did someone assist Darkie Chonco to take these weapons and hide them in the ceiling?
I do not remember, I just saw Darkie.
Yes.  And did it also include the spears, were not there, were they?  The spears, they were not there?  Did he just remove the firearms?
The spears were taken by their respective owners.
Yes, he just removed the firearms.
You said on many occasions that Darkie Chonco was in control of the firearms.  Aren't you making a mistake that the real person in control of the firearms was his brother, Damara?
No.  I did not see Damara handling the weapons, firearms.  The only person that I saw as responsible for those firearms, was Darkie.
So am I correct in saying that according to you, Damara had no specific role, either a leadership role or any kind of specific job in the hostel?
Even though I do not know what position he held, but he was highly regarded.  That is Damara Chonco.

I want to put to you that all the other applicants state that Damara Chonco was the person in control of weapons in the hostel, what do you say about that?  You are the only one that states that Darkie is actually the person that dealt with the weapons.
I deny, I dispute that.  They are just implicating Damara because he is dead.  I am not implicating Darkie falsely, I know Damara as well as Darkie.
Do you know if Darkie is still alive?
I said I do not know.  I do not know what has happened to him, I have been in prison.
Well, if you don't know if he is dead or alive, how can you give that reason that they implicate Chonco because he is dead, Damara, because he is dead?  Darkie may also be dead?
Damara died, I do not know with regards to Darkie.
So you specifically heard that Damara is dead?
What I am saying is that Damara died.  I do not know as to what happened to Darkie.

Chairperson, I just want one of the applicants to stand up to be identified.  Can the first row of applicants just stand up please.  Can this person on the left, just move out please.  Do you know that person, Mr Nosenga?  The one on the left, the other two may be seated.  I just want ...

I do not see him for the first time, but I do not remember his name.  He was an IFP member residing at the hostel.  He also appeared before this Committee.  I also know the others in the front row.  They are all members of the IFP.
So the person that is standing, you can't give his name?
I do not remember his name.  As I said before, there were many people living at the hostel.
Just to get clarity, but before these hearings here, when you were staying in the hostel, did you see him in the hostel?
That is correct.  That is the person standing.
Can you give any details about a position, or his situation in the hostel, or was he just according to you, a person in the hostel, just another person?
As I said before, he was an IFP member, residing at the hostel.  He was a hostel resident as he was an IFP member.
If I put to you, let me just get clarity, that is not, his nickname is not Gatchene?
When you referred to Gatchene during your evidence, you did not refer to that person?
I know a certain Gatchene, maybe there were two Gatchene's.
No, I am not stating he is Gatchene, but you didn't, when you spoke about a Gatchene, you didn't refer to him?
The applicant can be seated, thank you Chairperson.
Just for the record, what is the applicant's name?
It is Mr Mkhize, Bhekinkosi Mkhize.

Mr Nosenga, from your evidence now, I can gather that - no, let me first ask another question, the night of the attack, before the attack at the stadium, did you see the person we know now as Mr Mkhize?

I did state that I didn't see everyone, maybe he was also present, but I noticed there is an induna who was present at the stadium.  There were many people there, so he could have been present as well.
Yes, but you can't specifically remember him at the stadium, is that what you are saying?
Yes, I do not remember.  I cannot commit myself to having seen him.
Do you in fact say that you can't say that you saw him on the 17th of June 1992, at all?

As I stated before, there were many people in the stadium, there were many people who were from Natal, residing at the hostel, it could be that he was present, but I only noticed the induna, our leaders.  Some hostel residents, I did not know, some I knew them by their first names, some I did not even know their names.
Were you at the hearings already when Mr Mkhize testified?
Yes, but I was not in this hall, I was in another room in the same building.
But you could hear what he was saying?
I cannot remember, there are so many people who rendered their testimony here.  I did not hear him.

Mr Nosenga, I want to put to you that Mr Mkhize testified and so has all the other applicants, that he was a key person, in fact he was one of the two leaders of the attack on Boipatong.  Do you dispute that?

No, there were induna's there, Gatchene was present too.  I am saying the attack on Boipatong was, or should I say, did not involve only two people, not the Mkhize that he is talking about.  I don't know anything about that.
I further want to put to you that the other leader was Damara Chonco?  Can you answer that, the other leader was Damara Chonco?

No, that is a mistake.  Darkie, yes, was present, but I did not see him.  I am saying the one person that I saw in charge of the firearms, was Darkie Chonco, I did not see Damara.  Now, if you are saying it was Mkhize and Damara who were leading the attack on Boipatong, really that is something news to me.
I want to put to you that indicates that you were not part of the attack, because all the other people said that they were leading?
They are mistaken.  They are not giving you the right information.
At any meeting prior to the attack, did you see the person we know now as Mr Mkhize, making a speech or addressing the people?
I said no, I cannot say I saw him at any meeting that you are referring to.
I want to put to you that that will indicate that you did not attend any, that you were not in the hostel when those meetings were held.
No, I don't know sir, I was present at the hostel at the time of the meetings.  The meetings that I had already referred to.
I don't want to ask a question I have already asked, but do you agree with me that Darkie is much younger than Damara and Damara is an induna?
I don't know, but I know Damara to be Darkie's elder brother.  It is true, Damara is older than Darkie.
So, you also didn't see Damara at the stadium before the attack, addressing the people, giving instructions or anything of the kind?
No, I did say that I did not see him.  I saw Darkie Chonco at the stadium, at the meeting.
Did Darkie say anything at the stadium before the attack?

He was present at the stadium.  The one person that I remember very well, is Gatchene who said "the time that you have been moaning about, has arrived".  The one person who brought firearms along, was Darkie.  He was present at the meeting.
Mr Strydom, did I understand the import of your earlier questions where you said that Damara was the induna, are you saying that, are you putting it to him that Darkie wasn't an induna?
He didn't really answer that aspect.
Thank you Mr Lax.  What I am putting to you is that Darkie was just an ordinary resident.  Do you agree with that, that Darkie was not an induna, but he was just an ordinary resident?
Darkie was an induna, I did indicate that I didn't know about Damara Chonco.
What about Damara, was he also an induna?
I cannot remember very well, but he was a leader of the IFP.
I want to put to you that Mr Mkhize was arrested on the 30th of June 1992 in connection with the Boipatong incident.
I am not disputing that, people were arrested.
And I want to take it further, at that stage you were not in the hostel yet?
I don't know sir.  I don't know anything about that, I was at the hostel.
I want to put to you that you came to the hostel approximately the middle of July 1992?
That is a mistake sir.  I arrived at the hostel in 1991.
And that is the reason why you don't know this person everybody points out as a key kingpin in this Boipatong attack, because he was arrested before you arrived at the hostel?
No, no, that is not true.

You keep on saying that you came to the hostel in 1991.  I want you to have a look at your statement on page 18, the statement to Mr Kjellberg, the first paragraph reads
"... until January 1990 or 1991 I lived with my father at 671 Newman Road in Everton."
	What I want to put to you is that you are not even certain when you came to that hostel, you say it is either during 1990 or 1991, so there is some uncertainty in your own mind about when you arrived at the hostel, is that right?
No sir, that is a mistake.  I arrived at the hostel in 1991 and I was not staying with my father at Newman Road.  I grew up at my uncle's place in Everton.
Yet again then, something that is totally wrong in this statement?
Yes, I don't know about that.  The address is correct 671 Newman Road, Everton.
Sorry, do I understand that that is your uncle's address, not your father's address, is that what you are saying?
This is my uncle's address, it is true.  My father stays at Everton as well, but that is my uncle's address.
Mr Nosenga, do you know a person by the name of Holi Bajozi?
And do you know a person by the name of Oupa Moloi?
I am hearing that name for the first time.  I am not hearing that name for the first time.
Do you know him or don't you know him from the hostel days?

No sir, I am saying I am not hearing that name for the first time, it has been a long time since I saw him, but yes, I am not hearing the name for the first time.  But Holi is from Zone 7, I know him.
The second person I mentioned, Oupa Moloi, his nickname is Kgobi?  Do you know him?  It seems to me that you are saying the name rings a bell, but I want to know do you know Kgobi Oupa Moloi?
Yes, I know him.  Yes, he was not my friend, he was a member of the IFP, but he was not my friend.
Do you know a person by the name of Eugenius Mxiti?
No, I am hearing that for the first time.
No, no, I am hearing that name for the first time.  I would be telling a lie.  I do not know some of the people, there were many of us.
Yes.  The last person I want to ask you about is Teresa Mafokeng, do you know her?
No, no I don't know Teresa Mafokeng.

What I want to put to you about them, is that they testified at the criminal matter as accomplices, that testified for the State and their evidence were used to convict the accused or the applicants.  These people testified that Mr Mkhize was the leader that led, or he was the person that led the attack onto Boipatong, do you deny that?
No, I don't know anything about that.

I also want to put to you that these witnesses testified that - well excluding Teresa Mafokeng, but the first three people - that they were part of the attack and they saw no Police vehicles at any stage, during the course of this attack.
They are making a mistake.  There were casspirs at the time of the attack.  Some people of Boipatong survived the attack.
As far as Eugenius Mxiti is concerned, I want to put to you that halfway through the criminal trial, he was brought to the State Prosecutors by the ANC, and ...
Mr Mxiti was brought to the criminal trial and was handed over to the staff of the Attorney General by or through connections of the ANC.
No, I don't know anything about that.
And he testified that he did not see any Police vehicles during the attack?
No, that is a mistake sir.  I would not implicate the Police falsely, they participated during the time of the attack.
So what I am putting to you is that you are the only person that claims that he was part of the attack, that state that the Police was also involved in this attack.
That is correct.  I was present at the time of the attack, and the Police were present, using their casspirs.  They were present using casspirs.
I want to suggest to you that the reason why you are implicating the Police, is to get back at the people that tortured you?
No, that is not true.  I am not implicating them falsely for the purpose of revenge for the torture that I suffered, no.
Did you forgive them for the way they tortured you and mishandled you, manhandled you?
They were doing their job sir, it was their job that they tortured me.
So you didn't feel bad for what they were doing to you?  That was just their job, that is fine if they do it?
No.  I am talking about something that happened, I have no grudge against them.
Why did you go to Ulundi?
I did say that I went to Ulundi out of my own volition, to attend the Inkatha conference.
You were a youngster from the township, was there any other reason why you as a person who had never been to Ulundi before, went on this specific occasion?
No, I wouldn't know, but I did go to Ulundi.

All the people from the kwaMadala hostel that went to Ulundi for that conference, did they go in that vehicle of Damara, driven by Darkie?  They went in one vehicle, only that group of people that went?
I said I went to Ulundi in a kombi that was driven by Damara Chonco.
Oh sorry, driven yes, sorry, I've got it wrong way around.  Was Mr Vanana Zulu also in that kombi?
When you got to Ulundi, did you see other people from the hostel that was not in that kombi?
Yes, I did see them.  They had come, using their private vehicles.

I want to refer you to a document, Exhibit Z, unfortunately not - the second part of that document, I want to refer you to page, it is marked page VI, Chairperson, I see there has unfortunately been a portion cut off, but I will read from the original.  Now I am going to put to you minutes that were taken and you must tell me if you agree with these minutes or not.  On the 18th of July 1992, I think that was on a Saturday.
I don't recall, but we left on Friday, early in the morning.
Did Mr Zulu report back to the congress goers...
I think it, is it VI, is it?
VI, the page is marked VI.
I think it is the second - I think it is about the fifth page.
It is page 17 of Exhibit Z.
That is correct, I've numbered mine, and it is 17.
I am not going to mark the original.  The question I want to ask you before I read this portion to you, did Mr Vanana Zulu get onto the stage to report something to the people there?
Mr Strydom, we have gone through this.  I mean if you want to put the minutes to the witness, put the minutes to the witness and let's see what he has to say.
As it pleases you, Chairperson.  According to this minutes, Mtwana V. Zulu reported about Madala incidents.  Would that be correct?
So according to you he never spoke at all, is that what you are saying?

According to the minutes, I will read them then to you, he said that on Tuesday somebody came, a person of an age of 17 years, the man was coming to Madala from the township.  He pointed out that the man is round, and he was not forced to come to Ulundi.  Do you have any comment so far?
No, I don't know anything about that.  I don't know who this 17 year old is.

The name of the guy is Matanzima, he said that he was sent by ANC members to work after members of the IFP in Madala hostel.  He was ordered to monitor the movement of the five members of the IFP.  He mentioned that Mbatha is the man behind this.  If anyone refused to do what he is instructed to do, he will be sjamboked to death.  He also mentioned that he was also instructed to take number plates for the members of the IFP and then it carries on with something else, Mr Twala reported on the conference about the MK and their task since 1960.  You deny all this?
You say you did not hear Mr Zulu speak at the conference?
No, I did say at the beginning.
did you hear someone saying the things that Counsel has just read to you?
No, I did not.   I am hearing this for the first time here, I did not hear him say that.  I am hearing this for the first time here, now that he is reading it.
Do you or did you know a person with the name of Mbatha?

Mr Nosenga, I just want to also put to you seeing that this Exhibit W and Exhibit X were handed in, that according to this cell registers, Mr Keswa was not in the hostel on the 15th of June 1992 and he was not in the hostel on the 17th of June 1992.  What do you say about that?
I don't know anything about that.  I cannot say he was present on the 15th of June 1992, when the people were being attacked at Sebokeng, I don't know.
So according to you he did not take part in the drive-by shootings on the 15th of June, is that right?
I am saying I was with him, together with Ndlandla Ndlovu and Xindi.  He was released now and then from prison, so I cannot say really.
But you can't give any explanation why you did not see your friend, Victor Keswa from the 17th when you saw him during the course of the day, that you did not see him thereafter, is that right?
What possible explanation can he give you other than he did not see him then?  If he didn't see him, he didn't see him.
Yes, maybe - I want to rephrase.  When did you see him again from the time you saw him on the 17th, during the course of the day?
I said I saw him for the last time during the day, he was in the company of Peens.  I did not see him in the evening of that day.
Thereafter, when did you see him thereafter?  Did you see him thereafter, after the attack?
No, I did not.  I saw him for the last time on the 17th.
You last saw him on the 17th, during the day?
Yes.  You never saw him again?
So in your whole life, you never saw him again after that day, is that what you are saying?
I said I did not see him even on the 18th.

What we are saying is, you are being asked this and you must listen carefully, I know you have been giving evidence for a long time, the question you are being asked is, after the 17th, did you ever see Victor Keswa again at any time?  Not just on that day, on any other day or any other week or any other month?
If I mention the name Moses Mthembu, will you be able to identify that person?
Have you heard the name Moses Mthembu before?
If I am not mistaken, I think I heard about it before.  If I am not mistaken.
But you can't say if he was a person with a position in the hostel?
I would be lying, I do not know.

Well, I want to put to you that Moses Mthembu is the person in control of the hostel, he is an employee of Iscor and in that capacity he is the person who will hand out rooms and deal with all hostel affairs.
I do not know that.  I will not dispute it.  All that I am saying is that I was issued a room by Mtwana Zulu.

I want to put to you that if you were in the hostel since 1991, you would have arrived there at a stage when Moses Mthembu had been there before you and you would have stayed with Moses Mthembu for a long period, and you would definitely know him.  Can you give any explanation why you don't know him?
What I want to say is that I did not know many people from Natal who were employees of Iscor.

I am not going to belabour the point, all I can tell you is that Moses Mthembu has been in the Vaal and working for Iscor for many years, and he has been in the hostel since the beginning when that hostel opened or when it was reopened.
It is possible that he was residing at the hostel, because there are many people there.
Chairperson, just give an indication till what time you want me to carry on.  I think I've got half an hour's questions left.
One question?  Maybe I said something wrongly without thinking, but I've got one issue which I want to deal with and that is the happenings on the 18th.

Chairperson, I will try to be quick.  It is difficult to say, it depends obviously on the answers, I want specifics about what happened on the 18th and the reason obviously to find out if the witness was there on the 18th.
I have specific knowledge that was not canvassed that I want to put to this witness.

Okay.  We will adjourn at this stage, we will resume on Monday at nine o'clock.
COMMITTEE ADJOURNS
